facts.text: Petitioner owned land measuring about 284 bighas situated in village Narinderpura.
In the year 1956 petitioner transferred one half of the said land in favour of his wife Shrimati Charanjeet Kaur.
Excluding the land transferred to wife, the land remaining in hands of petitioner is below the ceiling prescribed under the Act.
Petitioner is in personal cultivation of his land.
On October 30, 1956, Act XV of 1956 was passed amending Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1955, adding Chapter 4-A and imposing ceiling on land under personal cultivation.

On January 14, 1959, Punjab Legislature passed Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Amendment Act, 1959 (Act III of 1959), providing that transfer or disposition of land after August 21, 1956, except in favour of certain persons, shall not affect State's right to surplus area.
On May 31, 1962, Special Collector, Chandigarh, served draft statement on petitioner holding certain extent of land as surplus area, including land transferred to wife.
Petitioner filed writ petition under Art. 32 questioning Collector's order.
On August 13, 1956, Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Second Amendment Bill, 1956 published in Gazette, fixing permissible limits.
Last Settlement in Pepsu area took place about 50 years ago.

legal_issues.text: Whether provisions of ss. 32A, 32D, 32E, 32FF and 32G of the Act are inconsistent with the second proviso to Art. 31A of the Constitution.
Whether provisions of s. 32FF read with r. 23A of the Rules amount to delegation of legislative power.
Whether provisions of r. 28 of the Rules are inconsistent with s. 32G of the Act, so Art. 31A is not a bar to enforcement of fundamental rights under Arts. 19(1)(f), 31 and 14.

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of ss. 32A, 32D, 32E, 32FF, 32G inconsistent with second proviso to Art. 31A, as s.32FF by fiction raises ceiling including validly transferred land, denying market value for land below ceiling.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 31A second proviso; s.32FF Punjab Act III 1959

petitioner_arguments.text: s.32FF read with r.23A delegates legislative power by leaving enumeration of relations to State Government without principles.

r.28 inconsistent with s.32G as it uses outdated last Settlement data (50 years old) for fair rent and soil classification instead of current yield from Khasra Girdawari, making rules ultra vires, no valid law for acquisition, infringing fundamental rights.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.32G; r.28; Land Revenue Rules 1929 rr.1-12

respondent_arguments.text: s.32FF valid retrospective provision to prevent evasion; Art.31A bars challenge.
No abdication in s.32FF as policy laid down for relations; r.23A valid.
Rules valid; decision in State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh precludes challenge.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh (1952 SCR 889)

court_reasoning.text: s.32FF valid legislative device for retrospective effect from Aug 21, 1956 to frustrate evasions post Bill publication; transfer valid between parties but ignored for State ceiling; land above ceiling so second proviso Art.31A inapplicable; Art.31A bars Art.19(1)(f) challenge.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature competent; relates to estate under Art.31A.

court_reasoning.text: s.32FF lays policy for relations (those for benami evasion); r.23A valid enumeration, omission of sister mistake but not indefiniteness.

r.28 valid; uses last Settlement yield but allows reclassification for changes; no evidence of abnormal yield increase in Pepsu; petitioner's affidavit lacks specific allegation of increased yield per acre; cannot hold ultra vires on facts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Acquisition under valid law; Art.31A bars challenge to Arts.14,19(1)(f),31.

holdings.text: s.32FF valid; second proviso Art.31A inapplicable as land above ceiling.
s.32FF and r.23A not invalid delegation.
r.28 not ultra vires s.32G on facts; Art.31A bars fundamental rights challenge.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga
precedents_cited.relevance: Holds 'acquisition' in Entry 36 List II does not imply compensation; distinguished as not directly on point of rules ultra vires.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition under Art.32; Art.31A bars challenge to agrarian law; second proviso requires market value for sub-ceiling land.

statutes_cited.name: Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Imposes ceiling (30 standard acres); deems surplus acquisition; ignores certain transfers; compensation per s.32G.

statutes_cited.name: Act XV of 1956 (amending 1955 Act)
statutes_cited.relevance: Adds Chapter IV-A, ceiling on personal cultivation.

statutes_cited.name: Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Amendment Act, 1959 (Punjab Act III of 1959)
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfers after Aug 21, 1956 ignored for surplus except to prescribed relations.

statutes_cited.name: Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Rules, 1958
statutes_cited.relevance: Prescribes relations for s.32FF; mode for fair rent and soil classification under s.32G.

statutes_cited.name: Land Revenue Rules, 1929
statutes_cited.relevance: Principles for fair rent determination applied mutatis mutandis under r.28.

outcome.summary: Court holds all challenged provisions valid; rules not ultra vires on facts; Art.31A bars fundamental rights challenge; no other question arises.

key_quotes.text: No person shall be entitled to own or hold as landowner or tenant land under his personal cultivation exceeding the Permissible limit, that is, thirty standard acres.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Section 32FF was added to frustrate such devices and to make the enforcement of the Act really effective.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We, therefore, hold that on the facts placed before us we cannot hold that the Rules are ultra vires the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects challenge to r.28 for lack of evidence.
